text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the idea is if we combine them together, would they work together? And there’s some evidence that radiation makes the immune system work better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So the complicating part about that study is that the vaccine, you know, is a little involved. You have to go to the Red Cross. They’ve got to call some, they have to kind of hook you up to a machine that kind of pass your blood through and pull out the, the cells that they’re going to make the vaccine out of. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And so it’s, it’s, you know, you’ve got to do a little bit of work to get the vaccine. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but that would be another possibility, I think, uh- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: -that we could consider. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, if you’re, uh, again, the easiest thing is going to be to do the hormone therapy straight up. Patient: Right. Right.

text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, if they all do well and nothing happens to them, then we treat three more men at a higher dose level, and if nothing happens to them, we go to a higher dose level. Um. Patient: With different people? Doctor: Different people. You know? I would have to check. Again, some of the things we’d have to clarify. Uh, it is – if you’re, let’s say you’re --come in at the second dose level, and you are on it and it, it’s not, the cancer’s not getting worse. Uh, does it make sense to go to the higher dose. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That those men are safe. Or, the fact that your cancer’s not getting worse, why would we change the dose? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, a lot of times, they don’t let us move up. Sometimes they let us move up if the next guys have tolerated it well. Patient: And showed improvement or something like that? Doctor: Um, uh, yeah, that would be tough. And if they were benefiting and you weren’t, maybe higher dose – I don’t know what the rules are. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But, oftentimes they don’t let us increase the dose.

text: Patient: anyway so so, with that one I continue on the Xtandi with uh, um… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: That’s not the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: Correct. And both medications would be provided by the study. Patient: I don’t know if my insurance would cover the Xtandi and the Xtandi is ten thousand dollars a month. Doctor: Yeah so I think chances are you insurance will cover it. Okay? Patient: But that’s a pretty significant consideration. Doctor: Yes oh absolutely and you know you have the exact indication for requiring Xtandi now. My concern is is it worth it because the Xtandi really did take us too far in terms of giving you control from the cancer. Patient: And without the Xtandi? Doctor: Correct.

text: Patient: What’s the Doctor: -that it may happen right after the first – Patient: What’s the, yeah, how about enlightening me on how much time are we talking about before - Doctor: So, so my plan right now is to give you about two or three courses and do a repeat scan. Patient: That’s uh - Doctor: So one time every three weeks is called one cycle. So today if you get it, that’s your first cycle of treatment. Next treatment will be due in three weeks from today. Patient: Oh it’s every three weeks. Doctor: Correct. Patient: So I would take two or three treatments? Doctor: Uh, I’m thinking right now three, three, then we do a repeat scan. text: Patient: Well, I’m looking at her right now. Go ahead and say what you have to say. (chuckles) Family Member: No. I mean, well, yeah, at the end. But I’m fine with whatever you want to do, but I had a question – Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: - about, uh, why do you think the PSA is continuing to grow or get higher with, uh, with him being on the medication? That’s the part that I’m not quite, uh, I don’t understand. Doctor: I mean, the most likely explanation is that the cancer is continuing to grow at a slow pace. In other words, maybe the pace of the growth has slowed down, but it’s still growing overall, which is why I said that there are a few disconnects in my own mind about this therapy is working around. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: On the one hand, the PSA would lead me to believe that it wasn’t, but the scans would lead me to believe, that at the very least, we achieved the stability. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, but I, I agree with you that, that usually, although not always, usually the PSA that is rising means that the cancer is growing overall. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that’s something to keep in mind. That’s why I’m not placing like all the emphasis on the PSA, but I’m certainly placing some emphasis on it, uh. Family Member: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know?

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. It comes with side effects because it’s never nothing without nothing. Patient: What is the side effects? Doctor: Number one, two and three is tiredness. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And tiredness isn’t that your brain isn’t functioning, functioning great. Patient: Just physically tired? Doctor: Physically tired and it’s a weirder tired not like you worked out in the yard for twelve hours and can’t do much, it’s just no get up and go. If that happens, we take a break and we reduce the medicine dose. Patient: Let me ask you something doc. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Can we, can we provide a pill that would give me a little, like a vitamin that would give me a little energy? Doctor: No I think the issue of you not having as much energy is that your cancer is starting to, sorry that your thing is starting to break through slowly, Patient: Right.

text: Patient: I don’t. Doctor: I think that you know it primed your immune system to help us for the rest of the way here. Uh it’s not something that we can measure, but it’s clearly um something that I’m glad you did. And it certainly didn’t cause the cancer to spread any more or anything like that. Patient: Well my quality of life is significantly better. Doctor: Good, good. How well are you controlling your urine right now? Patient: I’m good. I have a um. Family Member: He has a panty liner. Patient: I have a panty liner. Just like in case I sneeze, cough. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That’s I mean I’m full exercising. Doctor: Uh hum. That’s okay, good. So you’re not leaking when you exercise? Patient: No, no. no. Doctor: Oh good. Okay, so really going forward, there are sort of two approaches that folks take. The standard of care is that you um would get uh radiation to your pelvis, uh and most people, given the amount of disease you have down there, we also recommend that you get hormone therapy with the radiation. Um uh, so one standard of care would be radiation alone; the second standard of care would be radiation plus hormone therapy generally for two years, which sucks, quite frankly.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
